newsitem.title: SPAIN: Peseta debt/interbank market closing report.
newsitem.headline: Peseta debt/interbank market closing report.

text.p: Spain's debt market proved resilient on Thursday, recovering quickly from initial losses to close slightly higher as soon as U.S. Treasuries bounced back, dealers said.

Though prices near record highs were suggesting a cautious approach, traders said government bonds were well supported by positive inflation expectations. The April Consumer Price Index due out next week is seen falling below 2.0 percent yearly.
"The inflation rate next week is a key factor. Long-term futures can easily go above the 115 level," a Madrid dealer said.
Another sharp drop in CPI in April could prompt the Bank of Spain to cut rates by 25 basis points for the fourth time so far this year, analysts said.
"Today the stars in the market were two-year bonds. Dealers bought that segment in anticipation of a possible rate cut as early as Friday next week," a dealers said.
The April 1999 Bond, coupon 9.4 percent, ended at around 107.43/53, with a yield at 5.28 percent down from 5.31 pct.
